p: Honey has attracted great attention as a natural sweetener that promotes health because it contains a high quantity of reducing sugars, a noticeable content of enzymes, proteins, vitamins and minerals and a wide range of phytochemicals. Due to the diversity of plant metabolites in floral nectars, chemical profiles and consequently, antioxidant activities of honeys are diverse [ 5, 6, 7]. The oxygen radical absorbance capacity of honey (3–17 µmol TE/g) is comparable to that of several fresh fruit and vegetables (0.5–19 µmol TE/g) [ 8]. The benefits of honey on cholesterol homeostasis have been well documented [ 9]. Particularly, phenolic compounds such as catechin, quercetin, luteolin in honey are reported to improve coronary vasodilation, prevent blood clots and LDL-C oxidation [ 10, 11, 12, 13]. Several flavonoids in honey are in aglycon forms, making them readily bioavailable when consumed [ 14]. However, to date, the understanding of the molecular mechanism through which honey elicits its protection against oxidative stress and hypercholesterolemia is limited.
